Subjective: Back pain radiating to right leg, thigh, and foot for 1.5 weeks. Worse over time. Pain described as sharp. No relief with paracetamol/ibuprofen (max doses). Pain constant, no variation. Sleep disturbance: unable to sleep. Impact on daily life: stopped working, unable to lift heavy objects. No recent trauma. No numbness/tingling initially, but now reports some tingling. No bowel/bladder symptoms. No saddle area numbness. No loss of strength, but pain limits movement. Social: Works in supermarket, had to stop due to pain. Lives alone, manages with dog. Request: Concern about herniated disc, wants pain relief and sleep improvement.
Objective: Inspection: No visible abnormalities on legs or back. Strength: Normal in both legs. Sensation: Decreased on right lower leg (duller). Reflexes: Normal. Positive straight leg raise test on right. No tenderness over vertebrae. Gait: Pain evident on movement.
Assessment: Lumbosacral radicular syndrome, likely due to intervertebral disc herniation. No signs of cauda equina syndrome.
Plan: 1. Initiate pregabalin for nerve pain, titrate dose slowly. Advise on driving restrictions. 2. Refer to physiotherapy for core strengthening exercises. 3. Schedule follow-up telephone appointment in one week. 4. Safety net: Contact if worsening symptoms, loss of bladder/bowel function, or progressive weakness. 5. Consider advanced imaging (MRI/CT) if no improvement with conservative management.
